data.event: Meteorologists suspect coastal B.C. is now being nipped by a trend of colder than normal winter temperatures that could last a decade.
The Pacific Decadal Oscillation is a phenomenon of alternating phases in which offshore ocean temperatures tend to run warmer and then colder—for 20 to 30 years at a stretch.
A warm Pacific Decadal Oscillation phase was measured from 1920-1945 followed by a cold phase that lasted until 1975, bringing the Lower Mainland many severe winters.

event.title: ’s been a mixed bag: three cold years

data.event: Since then it’s been a mixed bag: three cold years until 2002, then four more warmer years.
“It is cold right now,” he said.

event.title: last fall) have been colder than seasonal, he added

data.event: Three out of the last four seasons (except last fall) have been colder than seasonal, he added.

For anyone wanting proof of the hardship endured in the winter of 2008-09, Fricska offers these Metro Vancouver stats for December-January-February, from the airport weather station: It was the coldest winter since 1992-93 and the 10th coldest since record keeping began in 1937.

data.event: For anyone wanting proof of the hardship endured in the winter of 2008-09, Fricska offers these Metro Vancouver stats for December-January-February, from the airport weather station: It was the coldest winter since 1992-93 and the 10th coldest since record keeping began in 1937.

For anyone wanting proof of the hardship endured in the winter of 2008-09, Fricska offers these Metro Vancouver stats for December-January-February, from the airport weather station: It was the coldest winter since 1992-93 and the 10th coldest since record keeping began in 1937.
Mean temperatures for the three months averaged 2.4 C, down from a normal of 3.6 degrees.

event.title: experienced many of its coldest winters in recent memory during the cold oscillation cycle from 1945

data.event: He noted B.C. experienced many of its coldest winters in recent memory during the cold oscillation cycle from 1945 to 1975—even though global air temperatures climbed steadily during that period.
He noted B.C. experienced many of its coldest winters in recent memory during the cold oscillation cycle from 1945 to 1975—even though global air temperatures climbed steadily during that period.
Yet more snow fell this week at some higher elevations around the Lower Mainland.
